attachments.fallback: <https://twitter.com/texasmichelle|@texasmichelle>: As #S4TF heads into maintenance mode, it’s a bit :exploding_head: to reflect on how much I’ve learned. The community and team members built an incredible space for each other to grow :seedling: Thank you all :heart:

elements.text: Seems like it's officially benched

text: So Julia is now really the only option for future diff programming, though it seems apple is still supporting compiler autodiff

elements.text: So Julia is now really the only option for future diff programming, though it seems apple is still supporting compiler autodiff

text: Jax certainly helped..I wonder what this means for dex also

elements.text: Jax certainly helped..I wonder what this means for dex also

text: Looks like the rumours were true... :confused:

elements.text: Looks like the rumours were true...

text: Wasn't its momentum due to chris lattner working on it?

elements.text: Wasn't its momentum due to chris lattner working on it?

text: I'm surprised it held on this long since he left

elements.text: I'm surprised it held on this long since he left

text: Well, the core team was reasonably active and one frequent contributor even told me it was being actively developed a couple months back

elements.text: Well, the core team was reasonably active and one frequent contributor even told me it was being actively developed a couple months back

text: This comment turned out to be extremely prescient: <https://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=24533937>

elements.text: This comment turned out to be extremely prescient:

text: I love how they change the first line of the readme from "S4TF is a next-generation platform for machine learning" to "S4TF was an experiment" haha

elements.text: I love how they change the first line of the readme from "S4TF is a next-generation platform for machine learning" to "S4TF was an experiment" haha
That's a helluva diff

text: <@U67461GUB> will likely want to read this thread.

elements.text: will likely want to read this thread.

text: Thanks. It seemed like a bit of a strange combination from the beginning but it was Chris Lattner’s leadership that pushed it through as far as it did.

elements.text: Thanks. It seemed like a bit of a strange combination from the beginning but it was Chris Lattner’s leadership that pushed it through as far as it did.

text: It is quite confusing, because now differentiability and numerics are part of core Swift but don't have any higher level libraries built on top of them.

elements.text: It is quite confusing, because now differentiability and numerics are part of core Swift but don't have any higher level libraries built on top of them.

text: I wonder if they were waiting until those landed. If you look at the penultimate design meeting, the agenda was "S4TF is moving to default <http://Swift.org|Swift.org> toolchains instead of building custom ones"

elements.text: I wonder if they were waiting until those landed. If you look at the penultimate design meeting, the agenda was "S4TF is moving to default
Swift.org
toolchains instead of building custom ones"

text: Waiting for the recording from today's meeting to hear what they have to say about all this

elements.text: Waiting for the recording from today's meeting to hear what they have to say about all this

text: Yea. I think there's still support from apple for at least   the numerics and autodiff, so interesting to see where they might go with that

elements.text: Yea. I think there's still support from apple for at least   the numerics and autodiff, so interesting to see where they might go with that
